entries.title: 49 detained Ivorian soldiers pardoned by Mali's junta leader
entries.description: The release of the Ivorian soldiers is meant to both send a good faith signal to Ivory Coast and show that the junta is in full control.

entries.title: 2022: The hottest year ever recorded in France
entries.description: Punctuated by climate extremes, 2022 is a symptom of climate change, according to Météo-France, with temperatures that could become normal by 2050.

entries.title: US House of Representatives: McCarthy fails 12th speaker vote but gained 14 GOP supporters
entries.description: The turnaround came after he agreed to many of the detractors' demands, including the reinstatement of a rule allowing any single member to call a vote to oust him from office.

entries.title: Israel releases Karim Younis, the oldest Palestinian political prisoner
entries.description: A member of Fatah, the 66-year-old Palestinian with Israeli citizenship was originally sentenced to death in 1983 for killing an Israeli soldier.

entries.title: Visionary and ever-evolving Japanese architect Arata Isozaki dies at 91
entries.description: The 2019 Pritzker Prize winner, one of Japan's first architects to incorporate external influences, died on December 29.

entries.title: French cartoonist Bastien Vivès under investigation over child porn complaint
entries.description: Two NGOs protecting children complained about images in Bastien Vivès' work featuring sex involving children.

entries.title: French court backs Miss France against feminists
entries.description: The group Osez le Feminisme had filed a suit against the pagent's promoters and producers, alleging they broke French labor law.

entries.title: War in Ukraine: Russia now controls only 16% of Ukrainian territory
entries.description: IN GRAPHS - After conquering 24.4% of Ukrainian territory in March, the Russian army retreated until it controlled only 16.5% in December.

entries.title: Paris' Moulin Rouge in hot water with animal activists over snake act
entries.description: The famous cabaret show is accused of immersing non-aquatic snakes in water.

entries.title: Macron promises overhaul of France's struggling healthcare system
entries.description: The French president vowed to recruit thousands of medical assistants, change the way hospitals are funded, and better fees for doctors ensuring the continuity of health care.

entries.title: 16,000-year-old carved stones found in North America
entries.description: These lithic tools are more than two millennia older than those attributed to the Clovis culture, long considered the first in the Americas. Researchers have questioned their similarity to weapons produced in Japan 20,000 years ago.

entries.title: War in Ukraine: Western military aid crosses new threshold
entries.description: After France pledged to send AMX-10 RC light tanks to Ukrainian forces, the US and Germany also promised to deliver armored fighting vehicles and Washington is expected to announce a new $3 billion aid package to Kyiv on Friday.

entries.title: In the US, even the dead can be composted
entries.description: Body composting, or the natural reduction of the bodies of the deceased, is gaining popularity in the American West. The practice helps to limit the high carbon footprint of traditional funerals.

entries.title: In France, electricity and gas prices have declined unexpectedly
entries.description: Mild temperatures and a drop in activity are partly to explain for a decrease in energy prices. However, their impact on household business bills will not be immediate.

entries.title: Pension reform: How long, and in what health, do the French live after 65?
entries.description: One of the French government's key arguments for delaying the retirement age from 62 to 65 is that life expectancy has increased.

entries.title: Rainfall in France is not enough to offset the effects of the 2022 drought
entries.description: In several regions, rivers are low, groundwater table recharge is slow and soils remain dry. After the trauma of the summer of 2022, public authorities' stance on sharing the precious resource seems to be softening.

entries.title: Mauro Vieira, Brazil's foreign minister: 'The position of President Lula is one of dialogue' with Putin
entries.description: In an interview with 'Le Monde', his first with a foreign news outlet, the foreign affairs minister in Lula's new government says he wants to 'reinstate Brazil on the international scene.'

entries.title: Poland increasingly turns its back on the Catholic Church
entries.description: Disaffection is especially noticeable among the younger generation, who perceive the institution as trampling on the right of women to control their own bodies and denying any sexual orientation other than heterosexuality.

entries.title: Judges drop probe into French Caribbean pesticide scandal
entries.description: For decades, the use of chlordecone sent cancer rates soaring in Martinique and Guadeloupe.

entries.title: French government eyes new savings to reduce debt
entries.description: On Thursday, Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire announced the implementation of annual budgetary reviews to control public spending by the central government and local authorities.

entries.title: Gianluca Vialli, former Italy, Juventus and Chelsea striker, dies aged 58
entries.description: Vialli announced he had undergone radiotherapy and chemotherapy in November 2018, having been diagnosed with cancer one year earlier.

entries.title: Ukraine claims Putin's unilateral ceasefire over as soon as it begins
entries.description: Reports of at least four Russian strikes in the southern Ukraine city of Kherson cast doubt on the Russian president's ceasefire.

entries.title: French museums gear up to win back Chinese tourists after borders reopen
entries.description: Even if establishments like the Palace of Versailles and the Louvre are not anticipating a rush, they are all preparing for the battle to win back highly-prized Chinese visitors.

entries.title: 'M3gan' review: The revolt of an effectively scary robot doll
entries.description: New Zealand director Gerard Johnstone's second feature film doesn't take itself too seriously – but works upon a rich history of sci-fi horror.

entries.title: From the Louvre to Palais de Tokyo, tourists are returning to French museums after years of restrictions
entries.description: After years of travel restrictions due to Covid-19, French institutions are seeing the return of tourists. However, even Paris' largest institutions, like the Louvre and the Orsay, have not quite recovered to their pre-pandemic levels.

entries.title: In Italy, Giorgia Meloni's government targets NGOs rescuing migrants at sea
entries.description: A new 'code of conduct' for humanitarian ships came into effect on Tuesday, outlining fines between 10,000 to 50,000 euros for the captain if rules are not followed.

entries.title: Emma Raducanu injures ankle ahead of Australian Open
entries.description: A tearful Emma Raducanu left the court after rolling her ankle at the ASB Classic in Auckland on Thursday.

entries.title: Alice Nkom: 'It is up to us Africans to have leaders capable of speaking as equals with France, China and Russia'
entries.description: 'From Dakar to Djibouti, a tour of the Africa-France relationship' (7/11). The Cameroonian lawyer believes that France still represents the free world and humanist values, despite the work that remains to be done to deal with the colonial past.

entries.title: Sweden's intensive forestry model is being called into question
entries.description: The Scandinavian kingdom's forestry practices are based on monoculture and clear-cutting, which are facing growing criticism because of their damaging impact on the climate and biodiversity.

entries.title: Dalia Ghanem: 'The Algerian regime never intended to democratize'
entries.description: Researcher Dalia Ghanem talks about the support systems and pillars explaining the regime's longevity in an interview with 'Le Monde.'

entries.title: 'An Islam of enlightenment': Charlie Hebdo's lawyer and the Paris Mosque rector in conversation
entries.description: In a joint interview, Richard Malka, a lawyer for 'Charlie Hebdo', and Chems-Eddine Hafiz, thz rector of the Grand Mosque of Paris, discuss their vision of the Muslim religion.

entries.title: War in Ukraine: Shaken by the New Year's carnage, the Kremlin is preparing public opinion for new mobilization
entries.description: After the bombing in Makiivka, which killed several hundred Russian troops, the flaws of the 'special military operation' in Ukraine are exposed.

entries.title: NFL: Buffalo Bills safety Damar Hamlin asked who won Bills-Bengals when he woke up
entries.description: Hamlin remains critically ill and in the hospital's intensive care unit, but he began to wake up Wednesday night, and it appears his neurological function is intact. Doctors have not yet determined the cause of his cardiac arrest during a game on Monday.

entries.title: Transition of the German industry accelerated in 2022
entries.description: Despite the halt in Russian gas deliveries, the German economy is proving to be more resilient than expected. However, its heavy industries are expected to decline.
